topic.title: Discussion: HW-M8
topic.msg:
Post questions about HW-M8. Use the first line of your post as the subject of the post.

Assignments: Section 7.9.1 probs 1,3,5,8,9 Section 7.10 1, 2,3,4

entry.title: radical pigeon
entry.msg: how to write assembly programs in 64 bit mode?

entry.title: married llama
entry.msg: There is a full Visual Studio example in the Irvine library zip file at irvine/Project64_VS2019.

entry.title: married llama
entry.msg:
From what I could tell, the main differences in Visual Studio is that you need to select the "x64" configuration and provide an entry point.

Select an x64 configuration for your project:
    Build->Configuration Manager->Active solution platform: x64
Project property changes:
    Properties->Linker->Advanced->Entry Point: main

Then you need realize that some MASM features are not supported or different in 64 bit.  For example, you need "end" at the end but cannot use "end main".  But the above settings should allow you to build example code from the book.

entry.title: thoughtless swordtail
entry.msg:
#4 ROR instruction

For #4, I would like to iterate through the key array and use the ror instruction with the amount being shifted as they value of the key at the index of the text % 10. However, when I try moving the value of the key into a register, then executing ror, it says "Error: invalid operands." Does the book want us to hard-code the amount-shifted operand for ror or is there a way to do this with a dynamic value?

entry.title: thoughtless swordtail
entry.msg: Ok, turns out you can only use CL as the register for the amount to shift with ROR.

entry.title: striking snipe
entry.msg:
Good to know.  Referring back to text book, the allowed types of operands given for SHL under 7.1.2 

  • SHL reg,imm8
  • SHL mem,imm8
  • SHL reg,CL
  • SHL mem,CL

This types of operands should be applicable to all shift operations.  An immediate 8 bit constant or a CL register, and it wont accept a variable or register sounds inline with the error

entry.title: dry cuckoo
entry.msg:
Hello some help needed and thanks in advance!

 

Section 7.9.1

8. Describe the output when the following code executes in 64-bit mode:
    .data
    dividend_hi  QWORD 00000108h
    dividend_lo  QWORD 33300020h
    divisor      QWORD 00000100h
    .code
    mov  rdx,dividend_hi
    mov  rax,dividend_lo
    div  divisor

    In 64-bit mode, the DIV instruction uses RDX:RAX as the dividend, and it permits the divisor to be a 64-bit register or memory operand. The quotient is stored in RAX, and the remainder in RDX.

    rdx: 00000108h RAX 33300020h/ divisor RCX 00000100h -> RAX = (Quotient) = 00000100h; RDX = (remainer) 

 

I looked at the text book example which is very similar but didn't understand the inner working of the solution. Can someone share your understanding on this? Thanks again!
